On Monday 04 August 2003 17:45, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> >So said Chris Dollin on 2003-08-04 --------------------
> >We have an interface (Graph) with multiple implementations (A and B).
> > [Some names have been changed to avoid complications.] I have a test case
> > AbstractTestGraph with an abstract method Graph getGraph(), where the
> > tests test the Graph(s) that getGraph() returns, and TestA/TestB define
> > getGraph() to return instances of A/B as appropriate. So far, so good,
> > and just as suggested in one of the Junit documents. The code for each
> > test case is nice and short.
> >
> >Well ... I lied about A and B; it's more like A, B, C, and X. And likely
> > to be more, since Y and Z exist but may not be properly included in the
> > test suite at the moment.
> >
> >(1) How can I write a test generator which takes A.class, X.class etc as
> >arguments and constructs the necessary suite?
>
> I didn't understand this question.
>
> True or false: you want to create a test suite consisting of tests for all
> the implementations of an interface. (Please answer.)

Erm ... no, that's not it, quite. Apologies for unclear writing (perhaps,
unclear thinking ...)

I want to write a method M which given a class C which is supposed
to implement interface I will return a suite which runs the abstract test
cases ATC for I with respect to the implementation C. I happens to be
Graph and the C's are implementations of Graph and there are enough
C's that writing out explicit subclasses of ATC for each C is a pain.

This makes it easy for the writers of the different C's to run the 
abstract test cases. 

> The obvious-to-me code
>
> >    public static TestCase makeMyTest( final Class someGraph )
> >        {
> >        class TestSomeGraph extends AbstractTestGraph
> >            {
> >            public TestSomeGraph( String name ) { super( name ); }
> >            public static TestSuite suite() { return new TestSuite(
> >TestSomeGraph ); }
> >            public Graph getGraph()
> >                 { return someGraph.getConstructor( new Class[] {}
> >).newInstance( new Object [] {} ); }
> >            }
> >        }
>
> This appears to try to build concrete test cases
> (http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?AbstractTestCases) on the fly given an abstract
> test case. I have never thought of doing this before, but it makes sense.

Yes, I thought so too. [I have a functional programming / Lisplike background;
higher-order programming comes naturally.]

> Assuming that this is what you're trying to do, then I assume you have:
>
>    * An abstract test case GraphTest
>    * An interface Graph
>    * Implementations of Graph

Yes [GraphTest is called AbstractTestGraph, but what's an alpha-conversion
between friends?].

> You would like to generate a test suite consisting of XTestCase for each
> implementation XGraph of Graph where XTestCase creates an instance of
> XGraph to test.

What's important is not to be able to create a suite of them all (although
that might be nice), but to be able to trivially able to create a suite for
each one to be plugged into the locally appropriate test-cases.

[When I say "suite" am I being sloppy? I really mean "a test that runs
lots of tests".]

> This is a neat question. Let me think about this.
>
> >So ... am I dead-ended in the wrong alley? Missing something obvious?
> >Missing something subtle? Any advice would be welcome. If I have to
> >hack junit source code I will, but I feel that surely I don't need to ...
>
> I don't think you are. Dynamic invocation handlers might be the order of
> the day, or something... This seems to be easy to do in a dynamic language
> like Smalltalk. :)

So far as I can tell, it would be easy in Java if classes nested inside methods
were allowed to be public. I suspect the restriction was not reviewed when
they added reflection to the official language ...
